title: Events
Create an Event

inline_content.Text: Create an Event

title: Mysql has its EVENT functionality for avoiding complicated cron interactions when much of what you are scheduling is SQL related, and less file related. See the Manual page
here
a
https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/create-event.html
. Think of Events as Stored Procedures that are scheduled to run on recurring intervals.

inline_content.Text: Mysql has its EVENT functionality for avoiding complicated cron interactions when much of what you are scheduling is SQL related, and less file related. See the Manual page
here
. Think of Events as Stored Procedures that are scheduled to run on recurring intervals.

title: To save time in debugging Event-related problems, keep in mind that the global event handler must be turned on to process events.

inline_content.Text: To save time in debugging Event-related problems, keep in mind that the global event handler must be turned on to process events.

title:
SHOW VARIABLES WHERE variable_name='event_scheduler';
+-----------------+-------+
| Variable_name   | Value |
+-----------------+-------+
| event_scheduler | OFF   |
+-----------------+-------+

content_resolved.code:
SHOW VARIABLES WHERE variable_name='event_scheduler';
+-----------------+-------+
| Variable_name   | Value |
+-----------------+-------+
| event_scheduler | OFF   |
+-----------------+-------+

title: With it OFF, nothing will trigger. So turn it on:

inline_content.Text: With it OFF, nothing will trigger. So turn it on:

title: SET GLOBAL event_scheduler = ON;

title: The above inserts are provided to show a starting point. Note that the 2 events created below will clean out rows.

inline_content.Text: The above inserts are provided to show a starting point. Note that the 2 events created below will clean out rows.

title: Create 2 events, 1st runs daily, 2nd runs every 10 minutes

inline_content.Text: Create 2 events, 1st runs daily, 2nd runs every 10 minutes

title: Ignore what they are actually doing (playing against one another). The point is on the INTERVAL and scheduling.

inline_content.Text: Ignore what they are actually doing (playing against one another). The point is on the INTERVAL and scheduling.

title:
DROP EVENT IF EXISTS `delete7DayOldMessages`;
DELIMITER $$
CREATE EVENT `delete7DayOldMessages`
  ON SCHEDULE EVERY 1 DAY STARTS '2015-09-01 00:00:00'
  ON COMPLETION PRESERVE
DO BEGIN
   DELETE FROM theMessages 
   WHERE datediff(now(),updateDt)>6; -- not terribly exact, yesterday but <24hrs is still 1 day
   
  -- Other code here

END$$
DELIMITER ;

content_resolved.code:
DROP EVENT IF EXISTS `delete7DayOldMessages`;
DELIMITER $$
CREATE EVENT `delete7DayOldMessages`
  ON SCHEDULE EVERY 1 DAY STARTS '2015-09-01 00:00:00'
  ON COMPLETION PRESERVE
DO BEGIN
   DELETE FROM theMessages 
   WHERE datediff(now(),updateDt)>6; -- not terribly exact, yesterday but <24hrs is still 1 day
   
  -- Other code here

END$$
DELIMITER ;

title:
DROP EVENT IF EXISTS `Every_10_Minutes_Cleanup`;
DELIMITER $$
CREATE EVENT `Every_10_Minutes_Cleanup`
  ON SCHEDULE EVERY 10 MINUTE STARTS '2015-09-01 00:00:00'
  ON COMPLETION PRESERVE
DO BEGIN
   DELETE FROM theMessages 
   WHERE TIMESTAMPDIFF(HOUR, updateDt, now())>168; -- messages over 1 week old (168 hours)

   -- Other code here
END$$
DELIMITER ;

content_resolved.code:
DROP EVENT IF EXISTS `Every_10_Minutes_Cleanup`;
DELIMITER $$
CREATE EVENT `Every_10_Minutes_Cleanup`
  ON SCHEDULE EVERY 10 MINUTE STARTS '2015-09-01 00:00:00'
  ON COMPLETION PRESERVE
DO BEGIN
   DELETE FROM theMessages 
   WHERE TIMESTAMPDIFF(HOUR, updateDt, now())>168; -- messages over 1 week old (168 hours)

   -- Other code here
END$$
DELIMITER ;

title:
SHOW EVENTS FROM my_db_name; -- List all events by schema name (db name)
SHOW EVENTS; 
SHOW EVENTS\G; -- <--------- I like this one from mysql> prompt

                  Db: my_db_name
                Name: delete7DayOldMessages
             Definer: root@localhost
           Time zone: SYSTEM
                Type: RECURRING
          Execute at: NULL
      Interval value: 1
      Interval field: DAY
              Starts: 2015-09-01 00:00:00
                Ends: NULL
              Status: ENABLED
          Originator: 1

collation_connection: utf8_general_ci

          Originator: 1

collation_connection: utf8_general_ci

title: Random stuff to consider

inline_content.Text: Random stuff to consider

title: DROP EVENT someEventName;
c
– Deletes the event and its code

inline_content.Text: DROP EVENT someEventName;
– Deletes the event and its code

title: ON COMPLETION PRESERVE
c
– When the event is done processing, retain it. Otherwise, it is deleted.

inline_content.Text: ON COMPLETION PRESERVE
– When the event is done processing, retain it. Otherwise, it is deleted.

title: Events are like triggers. They are not called by a user’s program. Rather, they are scheduled. As such, they succeed or fail silently.

inline_content.Text: Events are like triggers. They are not called by a user’s program. Rather, they are scheduled. As such, they succeed or fail silently.

title: The link to the Manual Page shows quite a bit of flexibilty with interval choices, shown below:

inline_content.Text: The link to the Manual Page shows quite a bit of flexibilty with interval choices, shown below:

title: interval:

inline_content.Text: interval:

title: Events are powerful mechanisms that handle recurring and scheduled tasks for your system. They may contain as many statements, DDL and DML routines, and complicated joins as you may reasonably wish. Please see the MySQL Manual Page entitled
Restrictions on Stored Programs
a
http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/stored-program-restrictions.html

inline_content.Text: Events are powerful mechanisms that handle recurring and scheduled tasks for your system. They may contain as many statements, DDL and DML routines, and complicated joins as you may reasonably wish. Please see the MySQL Manual Page entitled
Restrictions on Stored Programs
